raw_response: {"answer_index": 1, "answer_text": "Bacterial infection", "confidence": 9, "reasoning": "Otitis externa (swimmer's ear) is most commonly caused by bacterial infection, particularly Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. These account for approximately 90% of cases. While fungal infections (otomycosis) can cause otitis externa, they represent only about 10% of cases. Seborrheic dermatitis and herpes zoster are much rarer causes. This is well-established medical knowledge taught in standard otolaryngology curricula.", "evidence_quality": "normal"}
